Award.AwardTitle: High-Valent Nonheme Iron-Oxo Complexes: Synthesis and Reactivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research award in the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program supports work by Professor Lawrence Que of the University of Minnesota to generate synthetic analogs of high-spin iron(IV)-oxo intermediates that serve as the key oxidants for many nonheme iron oxygenases. In contrast, the vast majority of synthetic oxoiron(IV) complexes described to date are low-spin, which DFT calculations predict to be much less reactive than their high-spin counterparts. To test the DFT prediction, Professor Que and his team will synthesize complexes with high-spin Fe(IV)=O units and characterize them by X-ray crystallography whenever possible and by a combination of spectroscopic methods in order to gain detailed insight into their geometric and electronic structures. The abilities of the high-spin complexes to oxidize substrate C-H bonds will be correlated with their properties and compared to those of low-spin Fe=O complexes to determine what factors control Fe=O reactivity. A greater understanding of such factors will be important for the development of more effective C-H bond oxidation catalysts.

Oxidation processes are important in biology and in industrial settings. Gaining insights into how Nature carries out the oxidation of C-H bonds efficiently has important ramifications in the design of oxidation catalysts for large scale chemistry that will be more energy efficient, more environmentally friendly, and less wasteful of our resources.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nature uses iron in many of its enzymes to activate gaseous oxygen and incorporate oxygen atoms into its target substrates for a variety of important metabolic transformations. One subset of these enzymes consists of nonheme iron oxygenases that carry out functions such as the biosynthesis of antibiotics and neurotransmitters, the repair of DNA and RNA, and the recycling and reuse of biomass in the environment. Many of these reactions require the generation of a powerful oxidant within the enzyme active site that can break a strong carbon-hydrogen bond on the target biomolecule. The goal of this project has been to understand how these enzymes work by making small-molecule analogs of the highly reactive enzymatic oxidants. These reactive intermediates contain an unstable form of iron called iron(IV)-oxo, in which iron teams up with an oxygen atom to make a powerful oxidant.

During the funding period, we have developed methods to make such compounds and stabilize them at very low temperature, which has allowed us to characterize them by spectroscopic methods and analyze how they react with various substrates. We have even been able to crystallize some of these molecules and obtain their structures by X-ray diffraction, allowing us to visualize how the atoms are arranged in three-dimensional space. Among the compounds we have synthesized is the first systematic series of structurally-related iron(IV)-oxo complexes with a so-called “high-spin” state, where the four electrons in the outer shell of the iron do not pair up, just like those found on the enzymatic oxidants. Such high-spin iron(IV)-oxo complexes have been challenging to design and synthesize. The most recent example we have reported has to date electronic and reactivity properties closest to those of TauD-J, the best characterized iron(IV)-oxo intermediate in enzymes  With a series of these molecules in hand, we are beginning to understand what structural and electronic factors make them such powerful oxidants.

The results of this project have been published in 17 journal articles, and presented at over 30 conference and seminar presentations. The project has also contributed to the training of six PhD students, four postdoctoral scholars and one undergraduate.

 


Last Modified: 08/26/2015
Modified by: Lawrence Que
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Nature uses iron in many of its enzymes to activate gaseous oxygen and incorporate oxygen atoms into its target substrates for a variety of important metabolic transformations. One subset of these enzymes consists of nonheme iron oxygenases that carry out functions such as the biosynthesis of antibiotics and neurotransmitters, the repair of DNA and RNA, and the recycling and reuse of biomass in the environment. Many of these reactions require the generation of a powerful oxidant within the enzyme active site that can break a strong carbon-hydrogen bond on the target biomolecule. The goal of this project has been to understand how these enzymes work by making small-molecule analogs of the highly reactive enzymatic oxidants. These reactive intermediates contain an unstable form of iron called iron(IV)-oxo, in which iron teams up with an oxygen atom to make a powerful oxidant. During the funding period, we have developed methods to make such compounds and stabilize them at very low temperature, which has allowed us to characterize them by spectroscopic methods and analyze how they react with various substrates. We have even been able to crystallize some of these molecules and obtain their structures by X-ray diffraction, allowing us to visualize how the atoms are arranged in three-dimensional space. Among the compounds we have synthesized is the first systematic series of structurally-related iron(IV)-oxo complexes with a so-called "high-spin" state, where the four electrons in the outer shell of the iron do not pair up, just like those found on the enzymatic oxidants. Such high-spin iron(IV)-oxo complexes have been challenging to design and synthesize. The most recent example we have reported has to date electronic and reactivity properties closest to those of TauD-J, the best characterized iron(IV)-oxo intermediate in enzymes With a series of these molecules in hand, we are beginning to understand what structural and electronic factors make them such powerful oxidants. The results of this project have been published in 17 journal articles, and presented at over 30 conference and seminar presentations. The project has also contributed to the training of six PhD students, four postdoctoral scholars and one undergraduate. Last Modified: 08/26/2015 Submitted by: Lawrence Que
